intro: Thaspium trifoliatum var. apterum, commonly known as the three-leaved thaspium, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to certain regions of North America. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, characterized by its aromatic foliage and umbellate inflorescences. The plant typically grows to a height of about 30–60 centimeters and features trifoliate leaves with serrated margins. Its flowers are small and white, arranged in compound umbels, and it blooms from late spring to early summer. The variety apterum is distinguished by its reduced or absent stipules, setting it apart from other variants of Thaspium trifoliatum.
